author: RFI avec AFP
title: Le pape François hospitalisé à Rome pour une bronchite
text:
Le pape François hospitalisé à Rome pour une bronchite
Le chef de l'Église catholique est de retour à l'hôpital depuis ce vendredi 14 février. Il a été contraint d'annuler tous ses rendez-vous du week-end en raison d'une infection des bronches qui l'affaiblissait ces derniers jours. Un signe supplémentaire de la santé fragile du souverain pontife de 88 ans.
Publié le :
Une bronchite persistante a contraint François à revenir à l’hôpital Gemelli de Rome, là où il a déjà effectué plusieurs séjours, rapporte notre correspondant à Rome, Éric Sénanque. À l'issue de ses audiences du matin, au cours desquelles il a notamment reçu le Premier ministre slovaque Robert Fico, le souverain pontife argentin de 88 ans s'est rendu à l'hôpital, a annoncé le Vatican dans un bref communiqué. Il doit « poursuivre en milieu hospitalier les soins pour la bronchite dont il souffre encore », est-il expliqué. Le porte-parole du Vatican a précisé à des journalistes qu’il était « serein, de bonne humeur et avait lu quelques journaux. »
Ces derniers jours, le pape de 88 ans avait montré des signes de grande fatigue. Dimanche dernier, en pleine messe célébrée place Saint-Pierre, il avait interrompu son homélie. « Je m’excuse et demande au maître des célébrations de poursuivre la lecture parce que je manque de souffle », avait-il déclaré.
Lundi, le pape François avait reçu en audience le recteur de la Grande Mosquée de Paris qui avait été marqué par sa fatigue. Toutes les activités du chef de l’Église catholique ont été annulées jusqu’à lundi. Selon certaines sources citées par le quotidien Repubblica, son hospitalisation pourrait s’étendre à cinq jours. De nombreux messages de soutien ont été partagés après l’annonce de son hospitalisation comme celui de la conférence épiscopale italienne ou encore du maire de Rome.
Une santé déclinante ces dernières années
Sa dernière hospitalisation datait de juin 2023 pour une opération à l’intestin. Problèmes de hanche, douleurs au genou, opérations, infections respiratoires... Le pape a affiché ces dernières années une santé déclinante et subi plusieurs alertes, qui ne l'ont pas empêché de maintenir un agenda chargé au Vatican. Entre décembre et janvier, le souverain pontife était par ailleurs tombé deux fois, sans gravité, mais donnant des sueurs froides à son entourage.
Le chef de l'Église catholique se déplace depuis 2022 en fauteuil roulant en raison de douleurs persistantes au genou et doit s'appuyer sur une canne lors des rares moments où il se tient debout. Il porte aussi depuis peu un appareil auditif. Il a été contraint à plusieurs reprises de déléguer la lecture de ses discours, voire d'annuler sa participation à des évènements pour raisons de santé.
Malgré ces alertes médicales à répétition, le pape François conserve un emploi du temps chargé, avec parfois une dizaine de rendez-vous dans la même matinée. Il continue aussi de voyager et a même effectué en septembre dernier le plus long voyage de son pontificat : un périple de douze jours aux confins de l'Asie du Sud-Est et de l'Océanie.

title: 生活智慧王！繳個停車費竟變賺錢機會？點數經濟大爆發！ | 三立iNEWS | 三立新聞網 SETN.COM
text:
財經中心／師瑞德報導
▲點數經濟導入交通場域，讓停車場成為智慧生活的服務入口，ViVi PARK攜手中華電信，讓Hami Point可直接支付停車費與充電費，用戶綁定中華電信門號後，即可將點數轉換為Vi幣使用，中華電信用戶可用Hami Point兌換影城票券與商圈折價券。（圖／翻攝自ViVi PARK網站）
台灣地窄人稠，寸土寸金，人住的地方不多，停車的地方更少，停車場市場，成為兵家必爭之地，如何讓駕駛停車的誘因，業者無不絞盡腦汁，增加誘因。過去大家對停車場的印象，可能只是「找到空位、繳費走人」，但這個刻板印象正在被打破。隨著數位支付與點數經濟的普及，停車空間正逐漸轉型成生活服務平台。榮帝科技旗下的ViVi PARK，便在今年十週年之際，攜手中華電信啟動全新合作，將Hami Point正式導入交通支付場域，開創「停車即生活」的數位新日常。
根據榮帝科技表示，ViVi PARK自2023年起便積極從地端服務向雲端應用邁進，目前全台合作車位數已達近60萬格，並結合電動車充電站服務，形成一套智慧交通生態圈。而這次與中華電信的整合，則進一步將點數導入生活應用面，讓「點數變現金」的概念在日常停車、充電、加油乃至生活票券上全面實踐。
從2025年8月起，中華電信用戶只要透過ViVi PARK APP綁定門號，即可將Hami Point點數以1:1比例兌換為Vi幣，直接在平台上消費。這意味著，用戶可以用點數繳交停車費、支付充電與加油費用，甚至換購如影城票券、商圈折價券等實體服務，將點數從原本限定的數位商城延伸到更多實體生活場景。
榮帝科技董事長陳明賢指出，點數經濟的擴張已是不可逆趨勢，而交通與停車場正是點數落地的最佳入口。他表示：「停車場不該只是移動的終點，而是智慧生活的起點。這次與中華電信合作，就是希望讓一場停車，不只解決移動問題，更能成為用戶串接日常消費的起點。」
另一方面，這波合作也搭配一系列回饋活動。中華電信用戶完成門號綁定即可獲得Hami Point與Vi幣雙重點數；使用Hami Point消費達一定門檻，還能再獲額外贈點；首次儲值、申辦月租服務也提供實質折扣與免費停車等回饋。透過這種實用型激勵機制，鼓勵用戶養成日常以點數進行支付的習慣，進一步擴大應用場域。
除了原有停車場網絡外，ViVi PARK近年也積極擴展充電業務，旗下充電品牌「Vi POWER」已陸續在雙北、宜蘭、高雄等地完成建置，並聯合其他充電營運商共同推動「充電大聯盟」，打造橫跨北中南的綠能充電網絡。隨著電動車使用人口攀升、環保議題受關注，點數若能在充電領域中具實質效用，對於消費者誘因與整體平台黏著度將有顯著提升。
分析市場動向不難發現，近年全球大型電信與科技企業陸續跨足交通場景、導入點數經濟架構，美國AT&T與Lyft、韓國SK與Tmap的合作模式皆可看見類似趨勢。此次中華電信與榮帝科技的聯手，也代表台灣市場正逐步趨近國際發展軌跡，點數正從會員制度延伸為一種「替代支付機制」，不再僅限於購物回饋或抽獎。
不過，儘管目前點數支付的場域正加速擴展，業界也提醒，後續能否維持用戶黏著度、點數是否具備流通彈性、兌換機制是否夠透明，都是關鍵挑戰。消費者對於「點數是否真的有價值」仍相當敏感，因此如何設計更即時、貼近生活的回饋場景，將是平台端持續優化的重點。
整體而言，停車場作為城市生活中極為頻繁且剛需的觸點，未來極可能轉型成為連結智慧支付、生態應用與永續行動的重要節點。從一個單純停車的場域，擴展為吃喝玩樂的服務集結站，陳明賢表示：「我們不是在做停車，而是在打造一個生活平台。」隨著點數應用逐步深化，停車行為或許將成為日常中最自然的入口，進一步改變人們對交通與生活消費的想像。

author: Rani Molla
title: Now streaming with ads is getting more expensive
text:
It’s still cheaper — and more profitable — than ad-free!
When I
[last looked](https://sherwood.news/tech/netflix-ad-tier-subscriptions-arpu-value/) at streaming subscription prices this summer, it had been getting more expensive to stream without ads, as companies like [Netflix](https://robinhood.com/us/en/stocks/NFLX/), [Disney](https://robinhood.com/us/en/stocks/DIS/), and [Warner Bros.’](https://robinhood.com/us/en/stocks/WBD/) hoped to push consumers to their lower-cost but [often more profitable](https://sherwood.news/business/netflix-and-the-other-streaming-companies-want-you-to-watch-ads/) ad tiers.
Since then, many of these companies have raised their rates — particularly on ad-supported subs. Hulu went up $2 to $9.99 per month for ads and just $1 to $18.99 for ad-free. It was the same situation for Paramount+, whose ad price grew to $7.99 from $5.99, while ad-free went to $12.99 from $11.99. Meanwhile, Disney+ and Peacock raised their prices $2 for both ad-supported and ad-free tiers.
What’s going on? First off: they can. Second off: even if they raise rates on ad-supported subscriptions, those prices are still cheaper than ad-free. So raising prices on ad-free tiers, even if it’s less of a raise than on ad tiers, will still push people to the ultimately cheaper ad tiers, which are more profitable than ad-free.
Here’s Disney CEO Bob Iger saying just that:
“It’s not just about raising pricing. It’s about moving consumers to the advertiser-supported side of the streaming platform,” he said after
[today’s earnings report](https://sherwood.news/culture/disney-earnings-beat-thanks-to-sequels/). “The pricing that we recently put into place, which is increased pricing, was actually designed to move more people in the AVOD direction,” or advertising-based video on demand, “because we know the ARPU and interest in it from advertisers and streaming has grown.”
About 60% of all new subscribers chose the ad-supported plan. Some 37% of total subscribers in the US currently subscribe to that tier. Disney reported a streaming profit — $321 million in Q4 up from $47 million in Q3 — for its second quarter in a row.
Trump’s win sparked a 1,514% surge in Americans searching for how to leave the country, permanently. A burgeoning industry is here to help — for a six-figure price.
Of those who canceled their streaming service in the prior year, 34.2% rejoined in 2024, according to data from subscription-analytics provider Antenna published in
[The Wall Street Journal](https://www.wsj.com/business/media/a-new-streaming-customer-emerges-the-subscription-pauser-430a4eef). That’s up from 29.8% in 2022. In other words, more people are pausing rather than truly [canceling](https://sherwood.news/power/ftc-canceling-your-subscriptions-just-got-easier/) their streaming subscriptions. Call it the “Succession” phenomenon, in which consumers turn off and on their services based on what’s airing or what sports are in season. But as streaming subscriptions get [more expensive](https://sherwood.news/business/steadily-rising-subscription-prices-are-boiling-consumers-like-frogs/), especially if you [don’t want ads](https://sherwood.news/business/netflix-and-the-other-streaming-companies-want-you-to-watch-ads/), people are becoming more likely to turn them on and off.
New data from the National Association of Realtors, cited by our colleagues at
[Snacks](https://sherwood.news/snacks/power/us-homebuyers-are-older-and-wealthier-than-ever-as-campaigns-promise-housing/), found that the median age of first-time homebuyers in the US is now 38 — up from last year’s 35 and marking the highest recorded age from data going back to 1981.
Rocketing house prices, still-high mortgage rates, and limited inventory all make owning a home an
[increasingly expensive](https://sherwood.news/personal-finance/home-ownership-required-median-income-american-dream-unachievable/) part of the American dream.
The same NAR report also outlined that the median age of repeat buyers has soared to 61 years (nearly a third of whom paid with cash for their follow-up homes), while the median age of buyers overall has rocketed to 56 years, +44% from just two decades prior.
These factors indicate the growing prevalence of a “renter generation,” with fewer than one in four of all homes bought by first-timers. Even so, rent prices are still far outpacing wages in most major US cities: according to
[CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/10/31/hourly-wage-needed-to-comfortably-afford-rent-in-15-large-us-cities.html), the average hourly wage required to afford a one-bedroom dwelling is almost 3x the minimum wage in New York, 2.3x Los Angeles’ min wage, and 2.1x Chicago’s.

title: European parliamentarians spurred to act after witnessing Hamas cruelty - The Jerusalem Post
text:
It was a jam-packed day for many Croatian, German, Italian, and Lithuanian parliamentarians who had never been to Israel, let alone during a war between Israel and Hamas. For more stories from The Media Line go to themedialine.org
They packed into small buses and drove to Israel’s southern border, along the way stopping at what has become the visual story sites that speak to the ghastly and sadistic slaughter that Hamas inflicted on innocent civilians on October 7.
The first stop was a briefing by an Israel Defense Forces (IDF) officer before they were shown the wrapped body parts of victims at the military morgue on the Shura Army Base near Ramla, where there are still many unidentified body parts. Then, the politicians continued to the Sderot Observation Center, where they were shown a film taken by Hamas terrorists as they entered the city of Sderot and shot innocent civilians in cold blood.
They were briefed by Superintendent Micky Rosenfeld, the Israel Police’s spokesman to the foreign media, on the details and scope of the morning when Hamas invaded. He told the group that Sderot normally has more than 30,000 inhabitants, but now there are only 2,000 residents left in the city. A row of homes destroyed at Kfar Aza (credit: FELICE FRIEDSON/THE MEDIA LINE)
Italian MP Mauro Del Barba, from Italia Viva, told The Media Line that he had a better understanding of the situation after the briefings that day. “Yes, I was very impressed by this witness. Because we didn't know how many fighters came from the Gaza Strip ... so many more than 1,000. And we didn't realize that they had a bigger plan than the one we saw,” Del Barba said, adding, “and probably a plan to conquer the entire country and to provoke a big war.”
Rosenfeld said that the police and the Israeli government advised Sderot’s residents to leave the area because “it’s very, very dangerous.” Advertisement
More than 125,000 residents have been taken to hotels or are in other areas of the country, and Rosenfeld said that he sees the war lasting many more months.
The next stop on the tour was the car cemetery, which has become a monument of all the scorched, tangled, and shot-up cars that had lined the streets near the Re’im music festival. While there, a tow truck entered the lot with another car in tow that was about to be dropped off, many weeks after that horrific day.
A siren sounded as the group was visiting, and everyone took cover, running and bending to hide near a cement wall.
The rocket could be seen easily; Sderot residents have lived with this reality of taking shelter on an almost daily basis.
Back on the bus, the final destination was what remained of the once-vibrant Kibbutz Kfar Aza. The blackened walls, remains of shattered lives, and the remnants of a community that thrived were seen as the group passed a lifeless orange tree whose fruits were barely holding on.
Israel Lander, who has lived on the kibbutz for 30 years, guided the tour group along with an IDF spokesman. Both detailed the events of October 7. He spoke of 63 inhabitants who were brutally murdered, stopping at various fragments of homes along the way.
His white cropped hair, beard, and shirt stood out among the darkness of the burned ruins around him. Printed on his shirt was the famous “Bring Them Home Now” red circle, and in Hebrew, below it, in black letters, “Kfar Aza is my home.” Lander’s solemn face and tortured eyes told stories one can’t imagine.
Holed up and helpless in the shelter of their home on the morning of October 7, Lander and his wife could hear the Hamas terrorists shooting from the roof of their home, and from their living room at the young people who lived in homes lining both sides of the street directly facing theirs.
“We had luck; they left the handle of the door. But they stayed in my house. They made my house a war room,” Lander told the MPs.
With so much loss all around, it is interesting to note that none of the 36 members of Lander’s extended family on the kibbutz were themselves murdered or abducted on that terrible day.
In one home, that of Roee and Smadar Idan, they were shown a clothing closet where their two children, Michael and Amalya, ages 9 and 6, hid for the next 14 hours until help came. The terrorists killed their parents—their mother in the same room where they hid.
Their sister Avigail, then 3, hid with neighbors, who were ultimately taken hostage. On November 24, Avigail was among the hostages released.
The IDF spokesman pointed to the place, cut out of the mattress of the bed, where Smadar was murdered, and the bullet holes in the adjacent wall. The room was filled with shock. Over 100 decision-makers brought to Israel since October 7
Elnet, an organization that aims to strengthen relations between Europe and Israel, has brought more than 100 decision-makers to Israel since October 7, including seven delegations of European members of parliament.
According to Turkish-born Deputy Executive Director Yossi Abravanel, the delegations aim to leverage these leaders’ voices on their respective governments to bring legitimacy to the Jewish state.
“One way to do it is to bring politicians to Israel and show them the reality so they can testify in their media and in front of their people when they go back to Europe,” Abravanel told The Media Line.
Unlike 80% of the US congressmen and senators who have visited Israel, fewer than 15% of the European MPs have visited, so it's a sad reality, he added.
The politicians shared insights of their observations along the way. Lithuanian MP Aurelijius Veryga, of the Lithuanian Farmers and Greens Union, said that his country is on the border with Russia and Belarus.
He told The Media Line, “What we are trying to do in Lithuania is that we are changing legislation to allow some people, some military people, rifleman, to keep guns at home just to protect themselves if something like this would happen in our country.”
The Italian Senator Francesco Arcieri was even more blunt as he told The Media Line: “What we saw with our own eyes today is the result of this terrorist attack. I believe that the ferocity of Hamas is the ferocity of another world, and that is why I believe that Hamas should not live in this world.”

text:

Il Tar conferma la precettazione: 4 ore nel trasporto aereo e Tpl. Bombardieri: oramai il Garante è di parte, non più un arbitro. Landini sarà a Bologna, il segretario Uil a Napoli Intanto la Cisl firma un altro «contratto in solitaria»
Il Tar conferma la precettazione: 4 ore nel trasporto aereo e Tpl. Bombardieri: oramai il Garante è di parte, non più un arbitro. Landini sarà a Bologna, il segretario Uil a Napoli Intanto la Cisl firma un altro «contratto in solitaria»
[Edizione del 29 novembre 2024](/edizioni/il-manifesto/il-manifesto-del-29-11-2024)
Il quarto sciopero generale di Cgil e Uil in quattro anni coincide oggi anche con il Black Friday, e non è un caso.
La data però era già stata scelta da vari Cobas – senza l’Usb – e la concomitanza dei due scioperi generali ha aperto la strada all’ennesimo dimezzamento nei trasporti deciso da PrecettoLaQualunque Matteo Salvini, imbeccato dalla Commissione di garanzia sugli scioperi nei servizi essenziali – mai di profilo giuslavoristico così basso e mai così di nomina politica. «È diventato di parte, il Garante del governo – attacca il segretario Uil PierPaolo Bombardieri – abbiamo aperto una discussione molto franca sul diritto di sciopero, e invece si risponde sbattendo la porta. Noi abbiamo perso fiducia nel Garante, non lo vediamo più come un arbitro».
Ieri il Tar – ma c’erano pochi dubbi – ha confermato la legittimità della decisione rispetto a un ricorso di Cub e Sgb che accusano Cgil e Uil di aver solo annunciato l’impugnazione e la sospensiva senza averla fatta veramente, limitandosi a un ricorso sul merito della decisione che non poteva essere accolto d’urgenza – e dunque nel trasporto aereo lo sciopero sarà dalle 10 alle 14, mentre nel Tpl ogni città ha i suoi orari, mentre saranno rispettate le fasce di garanzia e i treni circoleranno normalmente visto che Cgil e Uil ne avevano già previsto l’esclusione per lo sciopero dello scorso weekend dell’Usb.
LA GARANTE PAOLA BELLOCCHI proprio ieri era alle commissioni Trasporti e Lavoro della Camera dove – «in una audizione imbarazzante» secondo Arturo Scotto del Pd – ha ribadito «il potere di segnalazione di un pregiudizio grave ed imminente ai diritti costitituzionali della persona»: «abbiamo valutato che far fare lo sciopero a tutte le confederazioni – ha spiegato Bellocchi – avrebbe determinato un disequilibrio, una violazione del diritto alla mobilità degli utenti». Insomma, per la Garante gli scioperi generali che bloccavano il paese e facevano cadere i governi – all’epoca della destra – non hanno più ragion d’essere.
Difficile che oggi si blocchi il paese anche perché la Cisl continua nella sua deriva governista, non fa uno sciopero generale da tempo immemore e nelle ultime settimane ha sottoscritto «in solitaria» il contratto dei pubblici Funzioni centrali – e presto potrebbe farlo nella sanità – e, sempre in un’azienda pubblica come Poste, ieri ha firmato un accordo «farsa» su 7.500 assunzioni e ha escluso Cgil e Uil da una procedura di raffreddamento, il tutto sempre assieme a piccoli sindacati corporativi.
Detto questo, la combattività di Landini e Bombardieri è coriacea e l’asse che ha isolato Sbarra oggi scenderà in piazza in ben 46 città, in tutte le regioni e gran parte delle province.
LA SCELTA DI TANTE manifestazioni «sul territorio» – rispetto alla spalmatura su quattro giorni e macroaeree del 2023 – si spiega con la volontà di dare spazio e voce alle tante vertenze locali e nazionali – a partire da Beko – che stanno colpendo lungo tutto lo stivale in queste settimane.
Maurizio Landini sarà a Bologna dove il corteo partirà da quella porta Lame, che fu teatro di una grande pagina partigiana, per arrivare a piazza Maggiore. Pierpaolo Bombardieri invece parlerà dal palco di piazza Matteotti a Napoli.
A Milano concentramento alle ore 9,30 in Largo 11 settembre 2001 e partenza in corteo con successivo arrivo in piazza San Babila.
A Roma il corteo partirà alle 9,30 da piazza Esquilino e si concluderà in via dei Fori Imperiali, dove interverranno i segretari generali regionali con conclusioni affidate a Francesca Re David, segretaria confederale della Cgil nazionale.
L’OBIETTIVO DELLO SCIOPERO, come da sottotitolo, è «cambiare la manovra di bilancio», rivendicando come la misura principale della terza del governo Meloni – il taglio del cuneo fiscale – sia figlia del successo del primo sciopero generale di Cgil e Uil, nel 2021 con Mario Draghi che l’anno dopo si decise a seguire la richiesta della piattaforma confederale firmata anche dalla Cisl. Proprio a dimostrazione che gli scioperi generali servono.
D’accordo con i motivi dello sciopero c’è tutto il fu campo largo. La segretaria Pd Elly Schlein annuncia: «Saremo al fianco dei sindacati e dei lavoratori e delle lavoratrici in sciopero». «Salvini e gli altri ministri, invece di precettare, dovrebbero prima di tutto imparare ad ascoltare», dicono dal M5s. Nicola Fratoianni e Angelo Bonelli di Avs saranno a Bologna con Landini.
